title: 103_s2476
content: The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. The "Spousal IRA" rule allows for a deduction based on the combined compensation of both spouses, with a limit of $2,000 or the total compensation of both spouses minus any deductions. This rule applies to certain married individuals. The "Spousal IRA" rule allows a deduction for the spouse's gross income if filing jointly and their compensation is less than the spouse's. Amendments include changes to section 219(f) and 408(d)(5), with an effective date for the revisions. Amendments to section 219(f) and 408(d)(5) include changes to deduction limits. Effective date for revisions is after December 31, 1994. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free for first homes, higher education, qualified long-term care expenses, or by the long-term unemployed. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free for first homes, higher education, and qualified long-term care expenses. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions are payments used within 60 days for acquiring a first home for the taxpayer, their spouse, child, or grandchild. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions are payments used within 60 days for acquiring a first home for the taxpayer, their spouse, child, or grandchild. The qualified acquisition costs include acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, along with settlement, financing, and closing costs. A first-time homebuyer is defined as an individual who, along with their spouse, had no present ownership interest in a residence. A first-time homebuyer is defined as an individual who, along with their spouse, had no present ownership interest in a principal residence during the 3-year period ending on the date of acquisition. The term 'principal residence' in section 1034 has the same meaning as when used in section 1034. The term 'date of acquisition' refers to the date a binding contract is entered into or construction of a principal residence commences. If a distribution from an individual retirement plan does not meet the requirements, a special rule applies. The special rule applies if a distribution from an individual retirement plan fails to meet requirements solely due to a delay in acquiring or constructing a principal residence. The distribution amount can be contributed to an individual retirement plan within 120 days, with certain conditions. Qualified higher education expenses include tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for enrollment at an eligible educational institution. These expenses can be for the taxpayer, their spouse, child, or grandchild. The amount is reduced by any income excludable under section 135. The term 'qualified long-term care expenses' refers to amounts paid for necessary long-term care services, including insurance coverage. These services encompass diagnostic, preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitative, and maintenance services required by an individual. The term 'qualified long-term care services' include necessary diagnostic, preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitative, and maintenance services for functionally impaired individuals, provided under a continuing plan of care. The term 'functionally impaired individual' refers to someone certified by a licensed healthcare practitioner as unable to perform daily living activities without substantial assistance from another individual, and these services must be provided under a continuing plan of care prescribed by a licensed healthcare practitioner. A functionally impaired individual, certified by a licensed healthcare practitioner, must be unable to perform at least 3 activities of daily living without substantial assistance. In the case of home health care services, this requirement is reduced to 2 activities. In the context of home health care services, a functionally impaired individual must be unable to perform at least 2 activities of daily living without substantial assistance. Activities of daily living include eating, transferring, toileting, dressing, and bathing. In home health care services, a functionally impaired individual must be unable to perform at least 2 activities of daily living without substantial assistance, including toileting, dressing, and bathing. A licensed health care practitioner for this purpose can be a physician, registered nurse, qualified community care case manager, or any individual meeting requirements set by the Secretary after consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. A qualified community care case manager is an individual or entity with experience in providing case management services, assessing functional and cognitive impairment, not a relative of the individual receiving services, and meeting requirements set by the Secretary. Penalty-Free Distributions for Certain Unemployed Individuals: An amendment allows distributions from an individual retirement plan to unemployed individuals after separation from employment. Individuals who have received unemployment compensation for 12 consecutive weeks can now make penalty-free distributions from their individual retirement plans after separation from employment. This amendment allows for distributions during the taxable year in which the compensation is received or the following year. Amendments have been made to allow penalty-free distributions from individual retirement plans for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses. Amendments allow penalty-free distributions from individual retirement plans for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses, effective after the enactment of this Act.
